questions.text: A 1-day old male neonate is brought in due to the presence of a unilateral cloudy cornea. The neonate was born via forceps delivery with no complications. Maternal history is significant for being HBsAg positive; however, adequate neonatal vaccinations have been ensured. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trauma The given case history and findings point towards a case of the cloudy cornea due to forceps injury. In unilateral cases, the commonest cause is trauma with rupture of Descemet’s membrane (forceps injury).

In a case with bilateral cloudy cornea , causes may be trauma, mucopolysaccharidosis, interstitial keratitis and corneal endothelial dystrophy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents with a history of tennis ball injury to the right eye. On examination, a red spot is seen on the macula. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Berlin's oedema Commotio retinae (Berlin’s oedema) . It is a common occurrence following a blow to the eye . It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region . It may disappear after some days or may be followed by pigmentary changes. Commotio retinae (Berlin's edema) : Damage to the retina's outer layers from a shock wave caused by a blunt trauma or blast injury to the eye. The shock wave produces swelling and degeneration of the retinal layers. It may be central, and so involve the macula, or peripheral, and so not involve the macula.

Retinal detachment. It may follow retinal tears or vitreoretinal tractional bands. Concussion changes at the Traumatic macular oedema is usually followed by pigmentary degeneration. Sometimes, a macular cyst is formed, which on rupture may be converted into a lamellar or full-thickness macular hole. Option: C . Retinal tears. These may follow a contusion, particularly in the peripheral region, especially in eyes already suffering from myopia or senile degeneration. Option: D . Retinal haemorrhages. These are quite common following concussion trauma. Multiple haemorrhages including flame-shaped and pre-retinal D-shaped (subhyaloid) haemorrhages may be associated with traumatic retinopathy.

questions.text: On a fundoscopic examination of a patient, a red dot is seen. He has a history of being hit by a tennis ball. What is the probable cause -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Berlin's edema Berlin's edema (Commotio retinae) is a common condition caused by blunt injury to the eye . It is characterized by decreased vision in the injured eye a few hours after the injury . Commotio retinae refer to traumatic retinopathy secondary to direct or indirect trauma to the globe. It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region . It may disappear after some days or may be followed by pigmentary changes. Commotio retinae (Berlin's edema) : Damage to the retina's outer layers from a shock wave caused by a blunt trauma or blast injury to the eye. The shock wave produces swelling and degeneration of the retinal layers. It may be central, and so involve the macula, or peripheral, and so not involve the macula. Retinopathy may be present at areas of scleral impact (coup) and or distant sites (contrecoup) including the macula. Commotio retinae in the posterior pole is also referred to as Berlin's edema

questions.text: This cataract is associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trauma Vossius ring occurs following blunt trauma which is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule of the lens It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens It is always smaller than the size of the pupil

Highyeild:

Changes in the lens after Blunt trauma to the eye. The lens may show the following changes: Vossius ring. It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens. It is always smaller than the size of the pupil. Concussion cataract. It occurs mainly due to the imbibition of aqueous and partly due to the direct mechanical effects of the injury on lens fibres. lt may assume any of the following shapes: • Discrete subepithelial opacities are of most common occurrence. Early rosette cataract(punctate). It is the most typical form of concussion cataract. It appears as feathery lines of opacities along the star-shaped suture lines; usually in the posterior cortex. Late rosette cataract. It develops in the posterior cortex l to 2 years after the injury. Its sutural extensions are shorter and more compact than the early rosette cataract. Traumatic zonular cataract. It may also occur in some cases, though rarely. Diffuse (total) concussion cataract. It is of frequent occurrence. Early maturation of senile cataracts may follow blunt trauma. Traumatic absorption of the lens. Subluxation of the lens Dislocation of the lens. Rosette-shaped cataracts following blunt trauma in the subconjunctival space (phacocele) or it may fall outside the eye.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy comes to the eye causality with a history of injury with a tennis ball. On examination, there is Periocular ecchymosis, edema and anaesthesia over the cheek. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blow-out fracture. Blowout fracture usually involves the floor of the orbit The source of blood is short posterior ciliary vessels

Highyeild:

Blow out fracture It results from trauma to orbit by objects like tennis balls, cricket balls, and human fists leading to fracture of the floor as well medial wall of the orbit Usually caused by a sudden increase in orbital pressure due to an object, where the object diameter is greater than the diameter of the orbital aperture Blowout fracture usually involves the floor of the orbit The source of blood is short posterior ciliary vessels It is of further 2 types - Pure blowout fracture does not involve orbital rim only floor fracture Impure blowout fracture involves the orbital rim and/or adjacent facial bones Signs Periocular ecchymosis, edema etc Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia Double diploma- occurs due to mechanical entrapment of both inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscle Enophthalmos - sunken eyeball X-ray ( water’s view) - teardrop/hanging drop sign is seen in the antrum of the maxillary sinus. Treatment- Avoid nose blowing Systemic antibodies Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Cold compresses Surgical repair is to be done within 10 -14 days of injury

It can be life-threatening. a sharp and severe headache, particularly around the eye. swelling and bulging of the eye(s) and the surrounding tissues. eye pain that's often severe. double vision. a high temperature. Option: C. Sphenoid fracture: Fractures of the sphenoid bone occur following injury to the orbit and base of the skull. Such fractures are important since they can cause loss of vision and damage to various neural and muscular tissues. Ocular injury is also commonly associated. Option: D . Middle cranial fossa fracture: Patients may present with altered mental status, nausea, and vomiting. Oculomotor deficits due to injuries to cranial nerves III, IV, and VI may be present. Patients may also present with facial droop due to compression or injury to cranial nerve VII. Hearing loss or tinnitus suggests damage to cranial nerve VIII

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was involved in a road traffic accident an hour ago and was rushed into the casualty by his friend. He reported that the patient was the one driving the car, was fully conscious and not under the influence of any medications or alcohol. You suspect the presence of blunt trauma and hence check accordingly. On examination, his vitals are within normal range. On systemic examination, you notice lacerations over the maxillary area and his right shoulder along with a 2*1 cm contusion on the upper arm, consistent with the pattern of injury. You also notice the following ocular finding. Following blunt trauma and the development of the described exam findings, all of the following put a patient at higher risk for corneal blood staining except:
questions.correct_answer: C. Sickle cell trait or disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sickle cell trait or disease Corneal blood staining usually occurs following trauma where a large hyphema develops within the eye. High pressure, long duration, and endothelial dysfunction allow blood breakdown products (haemoglobin, hemosiderin) to migrate into the corneal stroma resulting in yellowish-brown discolouration. Sickle cell trait or disease, in and of itself, is not a risk factor for corneal blood staining , but in these patients, blood clots may linger in the anterior chamber longer and cause high pressures. In cases of large hyphema, lowering IOP and removal or evacuation of the blood clot from the anterior chamber may be needed to prevent this complication. Once blood staining is present, it can take years for the material to leach out of the cornea, if at all.
